results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Sleeping beauty (Lotte Reininger)
results.brief_description: A version of the traditional fairy tale in animated black and white silhouette cut-outs. Lotte Reiniger developed this technique in Germany in the 1920’s used it to make films for British television.

results.title: The Sleeping beauty (Imperial Russian Ballet)
results.creator_credit: Elena Macheret, Maxim Krastin, Svetlana Kononchuk, Konstantin Sergeyev, National Video Corporation (International) and Gosteleradio
results.brief_description: The Imperial Russian Ballet at the Maryinsky Theatre in St Petersburg first performed this beautiful classical ballet, choreographed by Marius Petipa to the wonderful score composed by Tchaikovsky, in 1890. In this 1983 television production, tradition is carried on by the world renowned Kirov Ballet at the Leningrad Theatre of Opera and Ballet with principal dancers Irina Kolpakova (Princess Aurora), Sergei Berezhnoi (Prince Desire), Lubov Kunakova (the Lilac Fairy) and Vladimir Lopukhov (Carabosse) presenting a truly glorious performance. Also features the magical music of the Orchestra of the Leningrad Theatre of Opera and Ballet conducted by Viktor Fedotov and choreography by Oleg Vinogradov.

results.title: The Sleeping beauty (Bolshoi Ballet)
results.creator_credit: Shuji Fujii, Takeshi Hara, Primetime, RPTA, Videofilm and NHK Entapuraizu
results.brief_description: The Bolshoi at the Bolshoi presents Tchaikovsky’s “The Sleeping beauty” in three acts with scenario by Ivan Vsevolozhsky and Marius Petipa, based upon the tales of Charles Perrault. Features the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra conducted by Aleksandr Kopilov and choreography by Marius Petipa staged by Yuri Grigorovich. This beautiful fairytale ballet is performed by dancers Nina Semizorova (Princess Aurora), Aleksei Fadeyecher (Prince Desire), Nina Speranskaya (Lilac Fairy), Yuri Vetrov (Carabosse), Aleksandr Vetrov (Bluebird), and Maria Bilova (Princess Florine).

results.title: The Sleep of reason
results.creator_credit: Peter Jordan, Sue Mathews, Australian Film Commission and Mathews Jordan Production
results.brief_description: The exploding of the atomic bomb over Hiroshima on August 6, 1945 made possible the apocalyptic extermination of the human race. This complex and moving documentary traces the history of human visions of “apocalypse”. Through an exploration of the vast canvases of Heironymous Bosch and Bruegel, the Japanese “monster” movies of the 1950s and the home-movies taken at the Nevada site at Las Alamos where the first nuclear tests were undertaken, “The Sleep of Reason” is an insight into the unconscious fears that underlie religious myths of punishment and redemption. However, the explosion of the bomb over Hiroshima dragged the apocalypse from mythology into reality and since that cataclysmic event, humanity has had to learn to live with the knowledge that it has the power to destroy itself. Filmed in the rebuilt city of Hiroshima, the film interviews philosopher George Steiner, psychoanalyst Robert Lifton, art historian Donald Kuspit and film writer Vivian Sobchack who all offer interpretations on how the bomb has affected global culture. An excerpt from an interview with Robert Oppenheimer, who breaks into tears as he talks about his work on creating the atomic bomb, is also included in this remarkable film.

results.title: The Slave
results.brief_description: When a struggling young sculptor can’t support his family his Greek wife offers to sell herself as a slave. Cast includes Florence Lawrence, Harry Solter, James Kirkwood, Mack Sennett, Mary Pickford. Silent film with no intertitles.

results.title: The Slap
results.creator_credit: Penny Chapman, Tony Ayres, Helen Bowden, Michael McMahon and Matchbox Pictures
results.brief_description: The Slap is an Australian television drama series based on the multi-award-winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Penny Chapman, Tony Ayres, Helen Bowden, Michael McMahon and Matchbox Pictures
results.description:
The Slap is an Australian television drama series. It was first broadcast on ABC1 from 6 October to 24 November 2011. The series is based on The Slap, a 2008 multi-award winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

Filmed in Melbourne, Victoria, the series was produced by Matchbox Pictures’ Tony Ayres, Helen Bowden and Michael McMahon, with Penny Chapman serving as executive producer. The directors; Jessica Hobbs, Matthew Saville, Tony Ayres and Robert Connolly, directed two episodes each. The writing team included Emily Ballou, Alice Bell, Brendan Cowell, Kris Mrksa and Cate Shortland.
description_for_label:

The series is based on The Slap, a 2008 multi-award winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

Filmed in Melbourne, Victoria, the series was produced by Matchbox Pictures’ Tony Ayres, Helen Bowden and Michael McMahon, with Penny Chapman serving as executive producer. The directors; Jessica Hobbs, Matthew Saville, Tony Ayres and Robert Connolly, directed two episodes each. The writing team included Emily Ballou, Alice Bell, Brendan Cowell, Kris Mrksa and Cate Shortland.

results.title: The Sky Pirates (Captioned)
results.brief_description: When their model plane crashes at the Aero Club, Mike and Harry are befriended by ex-pilot, Charlie Bradford, and his niece, Maggie, who teach them to fly radio controlled planes. Charlie invites them to the test flight of his new long distance aircraft which is later stolen. When they learn that a diamond has been stolen from the French State Museum, they realise the plane is to be used to smuggle the diamond out of the country.

results.title: The Sky is gray
results.creator_credit: Stan Lathan, Whitney Green and Perspective Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The American Short Story”.
Based on a short story by Ernest Gaines. Deals with a young black farmboy’s visit to the dentist in a small Louisiana town in the 1940’s. The visit marks the dawning of his social and self-awareness. Commentary by Henry Fonda. Cast: Olivia Cole, James Bond III.

results.title: The Sky is blue
results.creator_credit: Richard Raxlen, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fanciful story, done in paper cut-outs, of a boy’s journey through the skies on the tail of a kite. He soars high above the earth, encountering birds, aeroplanes, the stars, a spaceship and other heavenly bodies before floating back to his starting point. An animated film for children. Film without words.
